summary: Frontend testing of the new Africa Map component using react-simple-maps completed successfully. The map displays the full African continent with East African countries (Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Rwanda) highlighted in green. City markers with pulsing animations are working correctly for Nairobi, Kampala, Dar es Salaam, and Kigali. All navigation links functional, theme toggle works, and no console errors related to the new map component.

console_errors.issue: React hydration warning: Invalid HTML nesting - span inside tbody in the comparisons table mapping
console_errors.impact: Does not affect visual rendering or functionality. Previously documented in iteration_3

passed_tests: Africa Map component renders correctly using react-simple-maps library
Full African continent shape is visible and clearly rendered
East African countries (Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Rwanda) highlighted in green color
City markers visible for Nairobi, Kampala, Dar es Salaam, Kigali with proper labels
Pulsing animation on markers working (4 animate-ping-slow, 4 animate-ping-medium, 4 animate-pulse elements)
35 SVG circles rendered for markers and animation effects
Landing page loads without console errors related to map
Hero section displays correctly with 'Your Money. Your Timeline.' heading
Navigation links work: About Us, How It Works, For Employers, For Employees, Pricing, Calculator
About Us page renders correctly with gradient mesh background
'Connecting Africa to Fair & Timely Pay' section displays map with stats (50,000+, 500+, $2B+, 4 Countries)
Country list chips visible (Kenya, Uganda, Tanzania, Rwanda with flags)

success_rate.frontend: 100% - All Africa Map features working correctly

context_for_next_testing_agent: Africa Map component at /app/frontend/src/components/AfricaMap.jsx uses react-simple-maps with world-atlas topojson. The map filters African countries by numeric IDs and highlights Kenya (404), Uganda (800), Tanzania (834), Rwanda (646) in green. Markers have custom CSS animations defined inline (animate-ping-slow, animate-ping-medium). City labels are positioned using absolute CSS with calibrated pixel positions.
